description: Chronology derived from a combination of dates using various methods.

The analysis of burnt/carbonised particles or fragments.

Sample is heated in an over at 550°C. Generally used to burn off organic matter.
High velocity rotation of sample to separate contents by density.
Treatment with hydroflouric acid, generally to remove mineral (silicate) particles from pollen samples prior to slide preparation.
The United Kingdom National Grid system, established by the Ordnance Survey under the name OSGB36.
Height from reference level/datum. Negative values are below datum.
Height from ground or lake/river surface. Negative values below surface. Note: for heights above standard sea level use altitude.
Depth from reference level. Negative values are above reference level.
Height above sea level. Negative values are under standard sea level.
Depth from ground or lake/river surface. Neqative values are above ground. Note: use altitude for relative to standard sea level.
Reduction of sediment by water floatation. Sample is washed through a seive to remove fine material and retrieve lighter organic matter.
Separation through 300 micron sieve. Large fraction saved.
Separation through 250 micron sieve. Large fraction saved.
Separation through 500 micron sieve. Large fraction retained.
Separation through 2 mm sieve. Large fraction saved.
Sample mixed with dilute hydroxide solution to spead up dissaggregation of sample.
Core taken using a Russian Auger
Core taken using a freeze corer
Samples taken using kubiena boxes
Monolith samples from exposed section or excavated pit
Samples taken in unspecified, non-rigourous method (e.g. excavator, spade, hands etc.)
Subjective estimation of (sample) volume - usually from bag size or bucket
Temporary record used for testing data entry where a field is manditory but no data exists as yet...
Reduction of sediment by floatation using paraffin (=kerosine, lysfotogen...). Commonly used for extracting insect remains, especially Coleaoptera...

Swedish geodetic reference system for local coordinates (where dd mm are replaced by the appropriate zone meridian.
NOTE: exactly how we handle the specific zones yet to be discussed - maybe one method entry per zone?

World Geodetic System.
System is used by the Global Positioning System.
Distance measures: Height, length, depth or width measured by device
Distance measures: Height, length, depth or width estimated

Any coordinate or grid system established for local recording of objects. Includes abstract archaeological site grids with origin (0,0) at any location.
I available, conversion factors for alignment wiwth standard reference systesm should be given in site notes.

Swedish Rikets Nät (National Grid) system. Full name "RT 90 2.5 gon V 0:-15". X = south-north, Y = west-east. Essentially superceded by SWEREF 99 although still in extensive use.
See http://www.lantmateriet.se/templates/LMV_Page.aspx?id=4766&lang=EN (NOTE: include URL as biblio link)

Swedish geodetic reference system, based on UTM zone 33N bit extended to include the whole of Sweden.
Coordinates are generally with decimeters of WGS 84 coordinates for the same place.
See http://www.lantmateriet.se/templates/LMV_Page.aspx?id=4219
The Irish National Grid System, established by the Ordnance Survey of Ireland.
A cross section perpendicular to the grain is cut with a saw.
Dendrochronological information extracted from a piece of wood by coring.
Dating by comparison of tree-ring sequences.
Korrektioner: Ingen landhöjnings- eller tidjordskorrektion
Argon39-Argon 40 radiometric dating

Age determined by comparison of pollen flora with reference data. A number of standard regional pollen zones have been determined through the compilation and zonation of multiple pollen profiles. Zonation is general achieved through the identification of significant changes in fauna (e.g. from birch to pine dominated), either manually or through cluster analysis.
Soil horizon classification according to strict International Soil Reference and Information Center (ISRIC) guidelines. http://www.isric.org/isric/webdocs/docs/ISRIC_TechPap19.pdf
Soil horizon calssification according to Goldberg & Macphail (2006) Practical and theoretical geoarchaeology. Variation and simplification of ISRIC system.

Soil horizon classification according to strict Food and Argriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) guidelines. ftp://ftp.fao.org/agl/agll/docs/guidel_soil_descr.pdf and http://www.fao.org/docrep/W8594E/w8594e0g.htm for more detailed descriptions.
Soil horizons given without any specified classification system.
Measurement of total phosphate content through citric acid extraction and photospectrometer
Amount of phosphates. Standard method using HCL instead of citric acid.

An evaluation of the proportion of organic matter present in a sample, measured by comparing pre-burnt and post-burnt sample weights.
Standard method:
A measurement of the ability of a sample to retain an induced magnetic field.
A measurement of the ability of a sample to retain a low frequency induced magnetic field.
A measurement of the ability of a sample to retain a high frequency induced magnetic field.

Amount of phosphates. Standard method: Inorganic phosphate content. Extraction by citric acid (2%). Based on Arrhenius and further developed by EAL. The amount of phosphate is specified as mg P2O5/100g dry soil.
Accelerator Mass Spectrometer Carbon-14 dating.
Conventional Carbon-14 dating.
Conventional Carbon-14 dating. Uncalibrated dates.

Age determined by comparison of pollen flora with reference data. A number of standard regional pollen zones have been determined through the compilation and zonation of multiple pollen profiles. Zonation is general achieved through the identification of significant changes in fauna (e.g. from birch to pine dominated), either manually or through cluster analysis.

Age determined to an archaeological period defined in 14C years. This is a bulk method for numerous techniques for assigning a deposit to a particular cultural period, where the period boundaries have been defined by radiocarbon dating. More specific method details should preferably be given as to how the date has been derived, but may not be available.
Age determined to historical period. More specific method details should preferably be given as to how the date has been derived, but may not be available.
Age determined to geological period defined in calendar years. More specific method details should preferably be given as to how the date has been derived, but may not be available.
Calendar years derived by unknown or unspecified method.
Age determined to geological period defined in C14 years. More specific method details should preferably be given as to how the date has been derived, but may not be available.

Age determined to geological period defined by radiometric methods but not necessarily radiocarbon (e.g. U-series). More specific method details should preferably be given as to how the date has been derived, but may not be available.
Dating through strategraphic association, placing the sediment (and enclosed artefacts) in the context of geological layers of known or unknown age.
Dating by relation to volcanic ash layer of a known calendar age.
Dating by relation to volcanic ash layer dated by radiocarbon.

Dating by artefact typology with calendar date. The form, design and material of an artefact may allow it to be placed in the context of a known sequence of artefact characteristics (a typological sequence). This allows it to be dated through the assumption that the typologies are correctly and independently dated. There is a slight danger or circular reasoning is the constraints of independent dating are not rigourously enforced, and a tendency for typologies to persist even if evidence suggests that there may be problems.

Dating by artefact typology with radiometric date. The form, design and material of an artefact may allow it to be placed in the context of a known sequence of artefact characteristics (a typological sequence). This allows it to be dated through the assumption that the typologies are correctly and independently dated. There is a slight danger or circular reasoning is the constraints of independent dating are not rigourously enforced, and a tendency for typologies to persist even if evidence suggests that there may be problems.
Unspecified dating method leading to an archaeological date in calendar years.

A sequence of radiocarbon dates may be compared with variation in the C14 calibration curve, and dates nudged so that they align with the curve. The method requires a sequence to be tightly dated and may be especially useful around flatter parts of the calibration curve. User discretion is required.

Dating method which relies on the predictable growth pattern of some lichen species. Some lichens (e.g. Rhizocarpon geographicum) exhibit colonisation, linear growth and non-linear phases of growth. By calibrating sizes against surfaces of known age (e.g. buildings, grave stones) it is possible to guage the age of exposure of a surface through the sizes of the lichens growing on it. A number of variations exist in terms of how to measure. The method has been applied to historical and archaeological remains as well as to geological features such as erosion surfaces and raised beaches.
Derivation of calendar date by reference to  geological processes, features or events (e.g. volcanic eruption, earthquake).
Dating based on historical documentation.
Unspecified dating method.
Dating by a radiocarbon method, the details of which are not provided in the publication or supporting material.
Dating by an unspecified radiometric method (information missing in publication).

Age determination based on the post-mortem decay (or racemization/epimerization) of amino acids in fossils. The method has primarily been used to date shells, and less sucessfully on bone, teeth and wood under some conditions.

Age determination by radiocarbon on humic substances extracted by pretreatment of sediments (e.g. peat, colluvium). A number of method variations are applied, aimed at dating different fractions of the sample (as opposed to the bulk dating of organic matter), including: humic acid fraction (alkali soluble) and humin fraction (alkali insoluble). Modern dates are generally determined through AMS, but older dates may have been aquired through standard counting.
method_name: C14 dating of humic substances in sediment

description: Period based dating method leading to a range of potential archaeological dates in unspecified years.
Dating using the release of stored energy properties of (mainly sonte) material previously exposed to the sun.
Göteborgs kommuns koordinatsystem. Gothenburg municipality coordinate system.
Acidity (pH)
Acidity (pH) (KCl 0,1M)
Malmö stads koordinatnät. Malmä city coordinate system. In use until 2008-01-01
Global coordinate system zone UTM 32 in WGS84 system. Last Revised: June 2, 1995 Area: World - N hemisphere - 6°E to 12°E - by country
Rikets höjdsystem 1970. Swedish national altitude system 1970.
Depth from surface lower sample boundary (depth is positive)
method_name: Depth from surface lower sample boundary

description: WGS84 UTM zone 33N
Qualitative soil horizon classifications used by MAL. Derived from: Troedsson, Tryggve & Nykvist, Nils (1973). Marklära och markvård. Stockholm: Almqvist & Wiksell
Site-specific grid or unknown site or sampling grid or coordinate system.
Conductivity in µS (H2O)
Plant macrofossil amount quantified by absolute volume
Depth from ground surface to upper sample boundary (depth is positive)
method_name: Depth surface to upper sample boundary

description: Depth from ground surface to lower sample boundary (depth is positive)
method_name: Depth surface to lower sample boundary

description: Official geodetic datum (reference system/projection) of Norway. UTM zone U32. EUREF89. https://www.kartverket.no/Posisjonstjenester/Kartprojeksjoner/
Preparation method: Sieving through 1.25mm seive (retaining seive contents)
Upper sample boundary positive
Lower sample boundary depth positive
Bartington MS2 & MS2D
Rikets koordinatsystem RT90 5 gon V
Preparation method: Sieving through 600µ seive (retaining seive contents)
Calendar years date provided by the calibration of a radiocarbon age. Exact dating method unspecified.
Calendar years date provided by calibration of an AMS radiocarbon age.
Age determined to geological period using undefined (or possibly multiple) method(s).
Dating using the interpolation of 14C dates from other samples (give details in dating notes)
Dating based on the trapped charges of electrons, electron spin resonance dating.
Dating based on the production of helium during the radioactive decay of uranium and thorium.
Dating based on the radioactive decay of chlorine 36
Dating utilizing disequilibrium in the decay of Uranium-238, Uranium-234 and Thorium 230.
Dating based on the radioactive decay of berylium 10.
Dating based on the radioactive decay of potassium into argon.
Dating through the synchronization of events according to Milankovitch cycles, casused by changes in the Earth's orbit, and their expected effects on climate.
Dating based on the radioactive decay of uranium-series isotopes protactinium-231 and uranium-235.
Dating based on the measurement of radioactive isotope lead-210, which is a product of uranium decay.
Dating based on the radioactive decay of uranium-234 to thorium-230, and the degree to which secular equilibrium has been restored between these
Dating based on the trails left in some glassy minerals as a result of the radioactive decay of uranium.

A piece of the ceramic sherd is cut off, fastened to a microscope slide, ground down to 0,03 mm, and polished. The tempering grains and clay is then studied under a microscope to determine clay content, fraction size, sorting and tempering content. These are all determined ocularly. The max grain size and total percent tempering is determined by marking the tempering grains in a photograph projected from the camera connected to the microscope and calculating in the program.

A raw clay sample and a sample of the ceramic sherd, or archaeological sample, is heated in a lab oven in 100 °C intervals, for a total of 30 minutes, up to 1000 °C. The colour change during and after heating is noted and compared to the Munsell Colour Chart to determine the firing temperature and firing atmosphere of the archaeological sample. The samples are then once more heated above 1000 °C, in 50 °C intervals, until they reach their melting point. The assumption for the thermal analysis is that the colour change of the ceramic sample doesn't occur until after the original firing temperature has been reached.
Collection of ceramic samples by unspecified means
Extraction and analysis of ancient DNA recovered from biological material (human, animal, plants, etc.)
